Package org.firstinspires.ftc.teamcode.helperClasses.bezierCurves

Class MathFunctions

java.lang.Object
org.firstinspires.ftc.teamcode.helperClasses.bezierCurves.MathFunctions
public class MathFunctions extends Object
This is the MathFunctions class. This contains many useful math related methods that I use in other classes to simplify code elsewhere.

    • clamp

      public static double clamp(double num, double lower, double upper)
      This clamps down a value to between the lower and upper bounds inclusive.
      Parameters:
      num - the number to be clamped.
      lower - the lower bound.
      upper - the upper bound.
      Returns:
      returns the clamped number.

    • normalizeAngle

      public static double normalizeAngle(double angleRadians)
      This normalizes an angle to be between 0 and 2 pi radians, inclusive.

      IMPORTANT NOTE: This method operates in radians.

      Parameters:
      angleRadians - the angle to be normalized.
      Returns:
      returns the normalized angle.

    • normalizeAngleSigned

      public static double normalizeAngleSigned(double angleRadians)
      This normalizes an angle to be between -PI and PI radians.

      IMPORTANT NOTE: This method operates in radians.

      Parameters:
      angleRadians - the angle to be normalized.
      Returns:
      returns the normalized angle between -PI (inclusive) and PI (exclusive).

    • getSmallestAngleDifference

      public static double getSmallestAngleDifference(double one, double two)
      This returns the smallest angle between two angles. This operates in radians.
      Parameters:
      one - one of the angles.
      two - the other one.
      Returns:
      returns the smallest angle.

    • getTurnDirection

      public static double getTurnDirection(double startHeading, double endHeading)
      This gets the direction to turn between a start heading and an end heading. Positive is left and negative is right. This operates in radians.
      Returns:
      returns the turn direction.

    • roughlyEquals

      public static boolean roughlyEquals(double one, double two, double accuracy)
      This returns whether a specified value is within a second specified value by plus/minus a specified accuracy amount.
      Parameters:
      one - first number specified.
      two - Second number specified.
      accuracy - the level of accuracy specified.
      Returns:
      returns if the two numbers are within the specified accuracy of each other.

    • roughlyEquals

      public static boolean roughlyEquals(double one, double two)
      This returns whether a specified number is within a second specified number by plus/minus 0.0001.
      Parameters:
      one - first number specified.
      two - second number specified.
      Returns:
      returns if a specified number is within plus/minus 0.0001 of the second specified number.

    • findNormalizingScaling

      public static double findNormalizingScaling(Vector staticVector, Vector variableVector, double maxPowerScaling)
      This takes in two Vectors, one static and one variable, and returns the scaling factor that, when multiplied to the variable Vector, results in magnitude of the sum of the static Vector and the scaled variable Vector being the max power scaling. IMPORTANT NOTE: There will be errors if you input Vectors of length greater than maxPowerScaling, and it will scale up the variable Vector if the magnitude of the sum of the two input Vectors isn't greater than maxPowerScaling. I know that this is used outside of this class, however, I created this method so I get to use it if I want to.
      Parameters:
      staticVector - the Vector that is held constant.
      variableVector - the Vector getting scaled to make the sum of the input Vectors have a magnitude of maxPowerScaling.
      Returns:
      returns the scaling factor for the variable Vector.

    • scale

      public static double scale(double n, double x1, double x2, double y1, double y2)
      Scales a number from one range to another.
      Parameters:
      n - number to scale
      x1 - lower bound range of n
      x2 - upper bound range of n
      y1 - lower bound of scale
      y2 - upper bound of scale
      Returns:
      a double scaled to a value between y1 and y2, inclusive
